definition:
A [*Smith number*]{} is a number which in a given base, the sum of its
digits is equal to the sum of the digits in its factorization. (In the
case of numbers that are not square-free, the factorization is written
without exponents, writing the repeated factor as many times as needed).
For example, 202 is a Smith number, since 2 + 0 + 2 = 4, and its
factorization is $2 \times 101$, and 2 + 1 + 0 + 1 = 4.

Prime numbers are not considered, since it is obvious that all of them
satisfy the condition given above.

In base 10, the first few Smith numbers are

4, 22, 27, 58, 85, 94, 121, 166, 202, 265, 274, 319, 346, 355, 378, 382,
391, 438, 454, 483 (sequence A006753 in the OEIS).

There are infinitely many Smith numbers that are also palindromic
numbers.

Smith numbers were named by Albert Wilansky of Lehigh University for his
brother-in-law Harold Smith whose phone number (493-7775) was the first
noticed Smith number.

Smith numbers can be constructed from factored repunits. The largest
known Smith number is (as of 2005)
$9 \times R_{1031} \times (10^{4594} + 3 \times 10^{2297} + 1)^{1476} \times 10^{3913210}$
where $R_{1031} = 2^{1032} - 1$.
